newsitem.title: UK: OPEC lifts March output to 26.9 mbpd - Reuter survey.
newsitem.headline: OPEC lifts March output to 26.9 mbpd - Reuter survey.

text.p: OPEC blithely lifted oil output again in March and showed no sign of stemming the rising tide of production which has contributed to a 30 percent oil price slump in the space of three months.

Wellhead crude production from the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries rose 130,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 26.90 million bpd in March from 26.77 million in February, a survey by Reuters of OPEC officials, oil companies and analysts found.

OPEC's drip-feed of extra supply, in tandem with rising volumes from non-OPEC producers, forced oil prices down to nine-month lows last week and left OPEC members facing the renewed possibility of budget squeezes.
Biggest OPEC producer Saudi Arabia, having enjoyed a $12 billion windfall last year, raised its 1997 budget projection for a barrel of Saudi crude by $2 to $16-$16.50.
Main Saudi export stream Arab Light on Monday was valued at about $15.50 for European buyers, down from $23 in January.
OPEC watchers say the chance of the 11-member cartel reining in supply to anywhere near its official 25.03 million bpd ceiling in response to lower oil prices remains slim at best.
OPEC's Gulf trio of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the UAE still have capacity in hand but supply restraint seems a thing of the past for the remainder of the group.

"Commercial considerations are now ingrained for most OPEC members," said one member country official. "There's simply no going back to the days when OPEC tried to support prices and left non-OPEC to walk away with increased market share."
"No one is planning anything at OPEC, that's for sure," said a senior OPEC official.
Rising Nigerian supplies were stunted in March by political protests which saw Shell facilities lose as much as 210,000 bpd over a 10-day period.
But the loss for the month cost Nigeria only 55,000 bpd, some of which was made by increases by other joint venture operators for an average 2.12 million bpd.
Iraq upped output in March under the United Nations oil sale but not by as much as some had anticipated.

After hiking supplies in early March to meet the deadline for the first 90 days of the U.N. deal, monitors said supplies fell back in mid-to-late March as buyers postponed liftings where possible to take advantage of more favourable April price formulas.
Exports in March averaged 600,000 bpd, up just 30,000 bpd on the month for overall Iraqi output of 1.18 million bpd.
Even OPEC's core Gulf trio now appears to be running consistently ahead of official quotas, though the transgressions remain relatively small compared.
Monitors put the UAE down slightly in March at 2.26 million bpd, 100,000 bpd over quota, as a result of minor maintenance on the Upper Zakum field.
Saudi Arabia and Kuwait also were running some 100,000 bpd in excess of official allocations at 8.13 million and 2.10 million bpd, respectively.
Venezuela, which abandoned quota compliance long ago, kept production steady in March at 3.18 million bpd, despite some weather-related export disruptions.
The Reuter survey seeks a best estimate of wellhead flows in OPEC countries based on the views of officials, industry monitors and analysts inside and outside member countries.
OPEC quotas are based on supply to market, defined to exclude movements to, but not sales from storage.
Table of average of findings from the Reuter survey are as follows:
MAR FEB JAN 3 MTH AV QUOTA
Figures, in million bpd, exclude condensate and NGLs. Quotas apply to supply, not wellhead output. Saudi and Kuwaiti data include Neutral Zone. (R) = revised.
-- London newsroom +44 171 542 8060
